|Title=Savoir évoquer le diagnostic clinique de trisomie 21 en postnatal.
|Description=Epidemiology and main postnatal clinical signs of trisomy 21.
|Rubric=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Elise Launay,Damien Sanlaville,Marie-Bérengère Troadec

The diagnosis is currently made most often (80-90%) in the ante-natal period. If this is not the case, the diagnosis is made in the neonatal period on the basis of the triad:

- Axial hypotonia

- Heart murmur on auscultation ([[Discovery of abnormalities on cardiac auscultation SD-018|discovery of abnormalities on cardiac auscultation]])

- Facial dysmorphia

Very rarely, the diagnosis may be made later (mosaic trisomy 21) based on the following factors

- Psychomotor retardation ([[Psychomotor development abnormality SD-115|psychomotor development abnormality]])

- Learning difficulties associated with immaturity

question.title: When is the diagnosis of trisomy 21 most commonly made?
question.description: The diagnosis of trisomy 21 is typically made in which period?

option_a.title: Postnatal period
option_a.description: The diagnosis is usually made after birth

option_b.title: Ante-natal period
option_b.description: The diagnosis is commonly made before birth

option_c.title: Late childhood
option_c.description: The diagnosis is typically made in late childhood or adolescence

option_d.title: Early infancy
option_d.description: The diagnosis is usually made in early infancy

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The correct answer is represented by a letter
